title: DIGCLASS Development Guide
text: document provides essential guidelines developers working DIGCLASS package. covers codebase structure, conventions, best practices help contribute effectively.

title: DIGCLASS Development Guide
text: Translation focus: package translates ISCO (International Standard Classification Occupations) schemas various occupational class schemas Data-driven: translations stored all_schemas all_labels data objects Utility-first: Common operations abstracted reusable utility functions

title: DIGCLASS Development Guide
code: R/ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ isco08.R          # ISCO08 translation functions ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ isco88.R          # ISCO88 translation functions ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ isco68.R          # ISCO68 translation functions ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ repair_isco.R     # ISCO data validation/repair ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ isco_fill.R       # ISCO zero-padding utilities ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ utils.R           # Core utility functions ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ all_schemas.R     # Translation data documentation ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ all_labels.R      # Label data documentation  tests/testthat/       # Comprehensive test suite vignettes/            # User documentation and examples _pkgdown.yml          # Website configuration

title: DIGCLASS Development Guide
text: Translation functions: isco{XX}_to_{schema}() (e.g., isco08_to_esec()) Utility functions: isco{XX}_{action}() (e.g., isco08_swap(), isco_fill()) Internal helpers: descriptive names (e.g., check_isco(), repair_isco())

title: DIGCLASS Development Guide
text: Extensive roxygen2: Use template functions utils.R consistency Real examples: Include practical examples actual ISCO codes Cross-references: Link related functions @seealso Template usage: Follow patterns like rg_template_title(), rg_template_intro()

title: DIGCLASS Development Guide
text: x: Input ISCO vector (always first parameter) label: Logical returning labels vs codes (default FALSE) to_factor: Logical factor output (default FALSE) isco_type: Optional ISCO validation (‚Äúisco08‚Äù, ‚Äúisco88‚Äù, ‚Äúisco68‚Äù) digits: Number digits ISCO operations (default 4)

title: DIGCLASS Development Guide
code: # Input validation and repair repair_isco(x, digits = 4)          # Fix malformed ISCO codes check_isco(x, check_isco)           # Validate ISCO codes count_digits(x, digits)             # Count digit patterns  # Translation engines   common_translator(...)              # Single-column translations multiple_cols_translator(...)       # Multi-column translations (e.g., ESEC)  # Data transformation isco_fill(x, digits = 4)           # Pad with trailing zeros isco08_swap(x, from, to)           # Convert between digit levels

title: DIGCLASS Development Guide
text: Simple translations: Use common_translator() - direct code--code mapping Complex translations: Use multiple_cols_translator() - requires additional variables (employment status, etc.) Always validate: Call repair_isco() check_isco() inputs

title: DIGCLASS Development Guide
text: One test file per R file: test-{filename}.R Comprehensive coverage: Test edge cases, errors, realistic scenarios Follow patterns: Use existing test files templates (especially test-isco_swap.R)

title: DIGCLASS Development Guide
code: # Standard test patterns test_that("function_name works correctly", {   # Basic functionality   expect_equal(func(input), expected_output)      # Edge cases   expect_equal(func(c("1", NA, "2")), c("1000", NA, "2000"))   expect_equal(func(character(0)), character(0))      # Error handling   expect_error(func(invalid_input), "expected error message")      # Messages/warnings   expect_message(func(input), "expected message") })

title: DIGCLASS Development Guide
text: Choose appropriate R file create new one following naming conventions Write function following parameter conventions validation patterns Add comprehensive documentation using roxygen2 templates Create thorough tests covering functionality edge cases Update vignettes function adds new workflow capabilities Update _pkgdown.yml include function appropriate section Run quality checks: devtools::check() must pass 0 errors/warnings

title: DIGCLASS Development Guide
code: #' Brief function description #' #' Detailed description with context and use cases. #' #' @param x A character vector of ISCO codes #' @param other_param Description of parameter #' #' @return Description of return value #' #' @examples #' # Simple example #' function_name(c("1111", "2222")) #' #' @seealso [related_function()] for related functionality #' @export function_name <- function(x, other_param = default) {   # Input validation   if (condition) cli::cli_abort("Error message")      # Core logic using utility functions   result <- common_translator(x, ...)      result }

title: DIGCLASS Development Guide
text: translating_between_hierarchies.Rmd: ISCO digit conversion utility functions repairing_isco_input.Rmd: Data cleaning validation **case-study-*.Rmd**: Real-world application examples

title: DIGCLASS Development Guide
text: Add new functions appropriate section _pkgdown.yml Group purpose: Translation functions, utility functions, etc. Test locally: Run pkgdown::build_site() pushing

title: DIGCLASS Development Guide
text: Use vectorized operations: Avoid loops possible Leverage existing utilities: Don‚Äôt reinvent validation/translation logic Cache lookups: Use all_schemas all_labels efficiently Test large datasets: Ensure functions scale appropriately

title: DIGCLASS Development Guide
text: Mixed digit lengths: Always validate consistent ISCO digit levels Missing validation: Use repair_isco() check_isco() consistently Inconsistent documentation: Follow existing roxygen2 patterns exactly Missing pkgdown entries: Add new functions _pkgdown.yml Insufficient testing: Test edge cases, NAs, empty inputs, error conditions

title: DIGCLASS Development Guide
code: # Essential development workflow devtools::load_all()        # Load package for testing devtools::test()           # Run test suite devtools::check()          # Full package validation devtools::document()       # Update documentation pkgdown::build_site()      # Build documentation website  # Quality assurance lintr::lint_package()      # Code style checking goodpractice::gp()         # Best practices check

title: DIGCLASS Development Guide
text: User-friendly: Functions ‚Äújust work‚Äù minimal setup Stata compatibility: Mirror CROSSWALK/ISCOGEN behavior applicable Comprehensive: Cover edge cases provide helpful error messages Consistent: Follow established patterns predictable API Well-tested: Extensive test coverage ensures reliability

title: DIGCLASS Development Guide
text: Existing code: Use similar functions templates Test files: Show comprehensive usage patterns Vignettes: Demonstrate real-world workflows Issue tracker: bugs feature requests Remember: doubt, follow existing patterns codebase. Consistency key maintaining high-quality package!

title: Case study: Exploring translations between social classes using the ESS data
text: Let‚Äôs suppose ‚Äôve received dataset contains International Standard Classification Occupations (ISCO) occupations respondents survey. particular, ‚Äôve got ISCO classification year 1968, bit outdated. package DIGCLASS can translate classiciation many others. Let‚Äôs load package use data ess contains ISCO68 European Social Survey. can see, dataset contains isco68, isco88 isco08. Assume second isco88 isco08 ‚Äôd like translate isco68 class schemas. DIGCLASS find functions translate isco68 begin isco68_. typed text editor isco68_ hit TAB, presumably ‚Äôll get auto-completion possible translations. ‚Äôs selected number translations can get isco68: can see, got translations done rather quickly. DIGCLASS aims consistent interface, meaning happen ISCO88 instead ISCO68, convention functions used: Similarly, can apply transformations ISCO08 following skeleton. one let‚Äôs see labs = TRUE check labels: Notice classes translate labels (isco88 oesch) others like isei siops actual numeric translations. ‚Äôs don‚Äôt label argument; continuous scales. Note swapping first part function (isco88_ isco68_) another ISCO always work isco** translations. sure check reference functions see translations available ISCO class schema.
code: library(DIGCLASS) library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union  ess #> # A tibble: 48,285 √ó 12 #>    isco68 isco88 isco88com isco08 emplno self_employed is_supervisor #>    <chr>  <chr>  <chr>     <chr>   <dbl>         <dbl>         <dbl> #>  1 5890   5169   5169      5414        0             1             0 #>  2 2120   1222   1222      1321        0             0             1 #>  3 7200   8120   8120      3135        0             0             0 #>  4 9310   7141   7141      7131        0             0             1 #>  5 6220   6111   6111      6111        0             0             0 #>  6 6220   6111   6111      6111        0             0             1 #>  7 9595   9313   9313      9313        0             0             1 #>  8 6000   1221   1221      1311        0             0             1 #>  9 6000   1221   1221      1311        2             1             1 #> 10 6220   6111   6111      6111        0             0             1 #> # ‚Ñπ 48,275 more rows #> # ‚Ñπ 5 more variables: control_work <dbl>, control_daily <dbl>, #> #   work_status <dbl>, main_activity <dbl>, agea <dbl> # Set `labels` to `FALSE` to obtain # the translated number instead of the label labs <- FALSE  # For some class schemas we use the number of employees that # the respondent has in their job. Here we're just recoding # some values that are missing. ess <- ess %>% mutate(emplno = if_else(emplno > 10000, 0, emplno))   # Translate `isco68` to many class schemas ess %>%   select(isco68, self_employed, emplno) %>%   transmute(     isco68,     isco88 = isco68_to_isco88(isco68, label = labs),     isco08 = isco68_to_isco08(isco68, label = labs),     siops = isco68_to_siops(isco68),     isei = isco68_to_isei(isco68),     egp = isco68_to_egp(isco68, self_employed, emplno, label = labs),   ) #> # code: library(readr) library(haven)  # For CSV, specify `col_types` isco_ready <- read_csv(isco_csv, col_types = list(ISCO08 = col_character(), ISCO88 = col_character())) x <- repair_isco(isco_ready$ISCO08) #> ! title: Repairing an ISCO variable
text: ISCO variables can become corrupted read R. Let show typical example. Suppose CSV file data ISCO occupations: CSV data string R need read read_csv. quite common ISCO columns read numeric column using functions read_csv read_dta (Stata files). Let‚Äôs see happens read column numeric: first 6 rows lost first 0. quite dangerous right now don‚Äôt know occupation 110 actually 0110 1100. Since can‚Äôt check every single occupation dataset confirm kept information digit, DIGCLASS function repair_isco tells corrects issues. Let‚Äôs run : functions tells us things: column numeric, warns need turn character Warns occupations digit less 4. input ISCO variable 3, 2 1 digit, can change using digits argument set another number. Shows transformation made harmonize occupations. transformations appending 0‚Äôs left total number digits. Ideally, want make sure always read data characters way can preserve original coding data. can read data characters like CSV: Note messages printed now. ‚Äôs function correct nothing needs done.
code: library(DIGCLASS) library(readr)  isco_csv <- "ISCO08,ISCO88 0110,0110 0210,0110 0310,0110 0100,0110 0200,0110 0300,0110 1000,1000 1100,1100 1110,1100 1111,1110" isco_ready <- read_csv(isco_csv, col_types = list(.default = col_double())) isco_ready$ISCO08 <- repair_isco(isco_ready$ISCO08) #> ! ISCO variable is not a character. Beware that numeric ISCO variables possibly contain lost data. See https://cimentadaj.github.io/DIGCLASS/articles/repairing_isco_input.html for more details. Converting to a character vector. #> ‚Ñπ ISCO variable has occupations with digits less than 4. Converting to 4 digits. #> ‚Ä¢ Converted `110` to `0110` #> ‚Ä¢ Converted `210` to `0210` #> ‚Ä¢ Converted `310` to `0310` #> ‚Ä¢ Converted `100` to `0100` #> ‚Ä¢ Converted `200` to `0200` #> ‚Ä¢ Converted `300` to `0300` isco_ready <- read_csv(isco_csv, col_types = list(ISCO08 = col_character(), ISCO88 = col_character())) isco_ready$ISCO08 <- repair_isco(isco_ready$ISCO08)

Occupation 2111 4 digit occupation contain zeroes. contrast, 2110 ‚Äúparent‚Äù category 2111. make even simple, think 2111 occupation ‚ÄúPhysicists astronomers‚Äù 2110 ‚ÄúPhysicists, chemists related professionals‚Äù. can intuitively group physicists broader category. Similarly, occupation 2110 ‚ÄúPhysicists, chemists related professionals‚Äù nested within broader group 2100 ‚ÄúPhysical, mathematical engineering science professionals‚Äù. Finally, broadest group 2000, general group definition ‚ÄúProfessionals. just intuitive explanation ISCO codes works. don‚Äôt remember category . can always look values better understanding DIGCLASS work translating everything . important thing remember something ‚Äôll want group fine grained occupations broader occupation categories. example categories within ‚ÄúPhysicists, chemists related professionals‚Äù grouped together. means ‚Äúconvert‚Äù column 4 digits 2 digits, example. DIGCLASS can function isco*_swap * ISCO preference. Let‚Äôs look ISCO variables ESS data DIGCLASS: three ISCO variables four digits can convert three digits: can see, three digit translation always zero, meaning translated broder group. can even broader group, translating 4 2 digits: can see two digit translation broader category original four digit occupation. Note can translate everything 4 1 way around: ‚Äôs can‚Äôt translate broader group finer occupation many specific occupation within broder group. Finally, note ISCO68, 1 digit groups missing (0000 1000 don‚Äôt broader category), translate digit 1 digit ISCO68 might missing values occupation within major group 0000 1000: Note 1 digit groups 2000, 3000, 5000 8000 translated correctly. Yet 1 digit group 1000 0000 never translated don‚Äôt exist ISCO68. DIGCLASS makes translation either way note ‚Äôll lose information translate schemas ‚Äôs NA.

what: Filling ISCO codes with trailing zeros
title: Translating between hierarchies for ISCO68, ISCO88 and ISCO08
text: working ISCO codes different digit levels, may need convert specific digit format certain functions. isco_fill() function makes easy automatically appending appropriate number trailing zeros: can also fill digit levels: particularly useful data contains ISCO codes 1, 2, 3-digit level need use functions expect 4-digit codes, isco*_to_oep(). function follows logic CROSSWALK/ISCOGEN Stata. ‚Äôs typical workflow combining isco_fill() DIGCLASS functions: isco_fill() function designed work seamlessly rest DIGCLASS ecosystem, making easy prepare ISCO data analysis regardless original digit level.
code: # Example with 2-digit ISCO codes filled to 4-digit (default) isco_2digit <- c("11", "21", "31", "61") isco_filled <- isco_fill(isco_2digit) #> ‚Ñπ Filled 2-digit ISCO codes to 4-digit format print(isco_filled) #> [1] "1100" "2100" "3100" "6100"  # Now you can use with OEP calculation oep_scores <- isco08_to_oep(isco_filled) print(oep_scores) #> [1] "87" "79" "63" "26" # You can also fill to other digit levels isco_1digit <- c("1", "2", "6") isco_fill(isco_1digit, digits = 3)  # Fill to 3-digit #> ‚Ñπ Filled 1-digit ISCO codes to 3-digit format #> [1] "100" "200" "600"  isco_fill(isco_1digit, digits = 2)  # Fill to 2-digit #> ‚Ñπ Filled 1-digit ISCO codes to 2-digit format #> [1] "10" "20" "60" # Simulate some 2-digit ISCO data isco_data <- data.frame(   respondent_id = 1:4,   isco08_2digit = c("11", "21", "31", "61"),   self_employed = c(0, 0, 1, 0),   emplno = c(0, 0, 3, 0) )  # Fill to 4-digit and calculate OEP and OESCH isco_data %>%   mutate(     isco08_4digit = isco_fill(isco08_2digit),     oep = isco08_to_oep(isco08_4digit),     oesch = isco08_to_oesch(isco08_4digit, self_employed, emplno, label = TRUE)   ) #> ‚Ñπ Filled 2-digit ISCO codes to 4-digit format #>   respondent_id isco08_2digit self_employed emplno isco08_4digit oep #> 1             1            11             0      0          1100  87 #> 2             2            21             0      0          2100  79 #> 3             3            31             1      3          3100  63 #> 4             4            61             0      0          6100  26 #>                                        oesch #> 1 'Higher-grade managers and administrators' #> 2                        'Technical experts' #> 3     'Small business owners with employees' #> 4                           'Skilled manual'

text: DIGCLASS R package aims make translation occupational social classes easy comprehensive. facilitates translation International Standard Classification Occupations (ISCO) 1968, 1988 2008 wide range social class schemes. package work progress implemented currently translations: ISCO68 ISCO88 ISCO68 ISCO08 ISCO68 SIOPS ISCO68 ISEI ISCO68 EGP11/EGP7/EGP5/EGP3 ISCO68 EGP11-MP ISCO88 ISEI ISCO88 SIOPS ISCO88 IPICS ISCO88 MPS88 ISCO88 EGP11/EGP7/EGP5 ISCO88 EGP11-MP ISCO88 OESCH16/OESCH8/OESCH5 ISCO88 ISCO88COM ISCO88 ISCO08 ISCO88 ISCO68 ISCO88 ORDC ISCO88COM ESEC - ISCO88COM must 3 digits ISCO88COM ESEC-MP - ISCO88COM must 3 digits ISCO88COM MSEC - ISCO88COM must 3 digits ISCO88COM WRIGHT ISCO88 OEP (1-4 digits) ISCO08 ISCO88 ISCO08 ISEI ISCO08 SIOPS ISCO08 Microclasses ISCO08 IPICS ISCO08 OESCH16/OESCH8/OESCH5 ISCO08 ESEC - ISCO08 must 3 digits ISCO08 ESEC - ISCO08 must 2 digits ISCO08 ESEC-MP - ISCO08 must 3 digits ISCO08 MSEC - ISCO08 must 3 digits ISCO08 ESEG - ISCO08 must 2 digits ISCO08 OEP (1-4 digits) ESCO ISCO08 Translation major/submajor/minor/unit groups ISCO68, ISCO88 ISCO08 Repair ISCO variables

title: An example data frame with data from the European Social Survey, round 6. ‚Äî ess
text: codebook columns : isco68: ISCO68 class schema 4-digits. isco88: ISCO88 class schema 4-digits. isco88com: ISCO88COM class schema 4-digits. isco08: ISCO08 class schema 4-digits. emplno: Number subordinates, . 0 employees, number 0 NA, data using DIGCLASS. self_employed: numeric vector indicating whether individual self-employed (1) employee (0). is_supervisor: numeric vector indicating whether individual supervisor (1, e.g. responsible employees) (0). control_work: likert-scale type question 0 10 0 whether individual control work/organisation decisions 10 complete control work/organization decisions. example, see variable iorgact European Social Survey. control_daily: likert-scale type question 1 4 1 means complete control decide daily work /organised 4 means control decide daily work /organised. example, see variable orgwrk European Social Survey. Another example recoding variable wkdcorga European Social Survey 8-10 1, 5-7 2, 2-4 3 0-1 4. work_status: self_employed non-employed respondents coded 2. unique values 1 = self_employed, 0 = employee 2 = non employed. variable constructed using variable emplrel mainact unemployed. main_activity: numeric vector 1 = respondent working, 2 = respondent education, 3 = respondent disabled , 4 = respondent paid work (household work, taking care children, etc..) 5 = respondent retired. variable can recoded using mainact variable European Social Survey.

text: Note translate using isco*_swap need provide arguments. first one specifies current number digits input variable. variable 4-digit occupations, 4. want translate 4-digit occupations 3-digits arguments = 4 = 3. See argument description possible values. well examples works. function accept 4 digit codes 4 digits. means 3-digit code 131 1310. codes 4 digits, even though code represented 3-digits (1310, 1320, etc..) Note translation can done higher smaller digits (4 3, 3 2, 3 1) never way around (1 2, 2 3, 3 4). ISCO68 might return NAs depending occupation code 4 digits groups 0000 1000. translation 4 digit codes 1 digit codes within groups return NA major groups. See ILO website: https://www.ilo.org/public/english/bureau/stat/isco/isco68/major.htm.

title: Translate 3-digit ISCO08/ISCO88COM to ESEC-MP ‚Äî isco08_to_esec_mp
text: function translates vector 3-digit ISCO08/ISCO88COM codes ESEC-MP codes. ESEC-MP class schema similar ESEC reassigns managers professionals (ISCO08/ISCO88COM codes 1 2) high/low managers profesionals. Similarly DIGCLASS::isco88com_to_esec, isco88com_to_esec_mp allows translate using simple full method. isco08_to_esec_mp allow translate using two different methods uses full method default. schema slight variation original ESEC logic used build like : occupations ESEC digit 1 ISCO 1-digit 0 1 subordinates, high manager occupations ESEC digit 1 self-employed 1 employee, high manager occupations ESEC digit 1 1-digit ISCO higher 1 either employee self-employed subordinates, high professional occupations ESEC digit 2 ISCO 1-digit 0 1 subordinates, lower manager occupations ESEC digit 2 self-employed 1 employee, lower manager occupations ESEC digit 2 1-digit ISCO higher 1 either employee self-employed subordinates, lower professional translation created Stata file shared Oscar Smallenbroek called "ESEC-MP.". info, please contact author. function accept 3 digit codes 4 digits. means 3-digit code 131 1310. codes 4 digits, even though code represented 3-digits (1310, 1320, etc..) information class schema, please checkthe references : Smallenbroek O, Hertel F, Barone C (2022) Measuring class hierarchies post-industrial societies: criterion construct validation EGP ESEC across 31 countries.¬†Sociological Methods & Research. Epub ahead print 11 November. https://doi.org/10.1177/00491241221134522

title: Translates 2-digit ISCO08 to ESEG. ‚Äî isco08_to_eseg
text: x character vector 2-digit ISCO codes. 4-digit equivalent instead 13, code 1300, 4-digit version 2-digit ISCO. work_status numeric vector values 0 3 1 = self_employed, 0 = employee 2 = non employed. main_activity numeric vector values 1 5 1 = respondent working, 2 = respondent education, 3 = respondent disabled , 4 = respondent paid work (household work, taking care children, etc..) 5 = respondent retired. example, see variable mainact European Social Survey. age numeric vector ages respondent. type type translation make. Possible values "one-digit" "two-digit". "one-digit" translation returns broad summary based translation 9 categories, whereas "two-digit" translation returns much bigger ESEG translation 25 categories. label logical value indicating whether return labels translated ESEG codes (default FALSE). to_factor logical value indicating whether return factor instead character. order labels taken sorted codes ESEG can found source code function.

Morris, K., (2024) Occupational earning potential: new measure social hierarchy applied Europe, JRC Labour, Education Technology working paper series 2024/06, European Commission, Seville, JRC139883. https://joint-research-centre.ec.europa.eu/scientific-activities-z/employment/jrc-labour-education--technology-working-paper-series_en Oesch, D., Lipps, O., Shahbazian, R., Bihagen, E. (2) Higher ISCOs codes filled codes lower ISCO-levels (say: ISCO-1 code 6 becomes ISCO-2 code 60, becomes ISCO-3 code 600, becomes ISCO-4 code 6000). translation now fixes issues works fine.

title: Translate 4-digit ISCO88/ISCO68 to EGP-MP ‚Äî isco88_to_egp_mp
text: EGP-MP class schema similar EGP reassigns managers professionals (ISCO88/ISCO68 codes 1 2) high/low managers profesionals. schema slight variation original EGP logic used build like : occupations EGP digit 1 ISCO 1-digit 0 1 subordinates, high manager occupations EGP digit 1 self-employed 1 employee, high manager occupations EGP digit 1 1-digit ISCO higher 1 either employee self-employed subordinates, high professional occupations EGP digit 2 ISCO 1-digit 0 1 subordinates, lower manager occupations EGP digit 2 self-employed 1 employee, lower manager occupations EGP digit 2 1-digit ISCO higher 1 either employee self-employed subordinates, lower professional translation created Stata file shared Oscar Smallenbroek called "EGP-MP.". info, please contact author. information class schema, please checkthe references : Smallenbroek O, Hertel F, Barone C (2022) Measuring class hierarchies post-industrial societies: criterion construct validation EGP ESEC across 31 countries.¬†Sociological Methods & Research. Epub ahead print 11 November. https://doi.org/10.1177/00491241221134522

title: Translates 4-digit ISCO88COM to WRIGHT. ‚Äî isco88com_to_wright
text: x character vector 4-digit ISCO codes. 4-digit equivalent instead 131, code 1310, 4-digit version 4-digit ISCO. is_supervisor numeric vector indicating whether individual supervisor (1, e.g. responsible employees) (0). self_employed numeric vector indicating whether individual self-employed (1) employee (0). n_employees numeric vector indicating number employees respondent. control_work likert-scale type question 0 10 0 whether individual control work/organisation decisions 10 complete control work/organization decisions. example, see variable iorgact European Social Survey. control_daily likert-scale type question 1 4 1 means complete control decide daily work /organised 4 means control decide daily work /organised. example, see variable orgwrk European Social Survey. Another example recoding variable wkdcorga European Social Survey 8-10 1, 5-7 2, 2-4 3 0-1 4. type type translation make. Possible values "simple", "decision-making" "power-class". label logical value indicating whether return labels translated WRIGHT codes (default FALSE). to_factor logical value indicating whether return factor instead character. order labels taken sorted codes WRIGHT can found source code function.

text: translation implemented function originally developed Erik Olin Wright. three possible types translations: "simple" version, "decision-making" version "power-class" version. translation implemented following SPSS script H√•kon Leiulfsrud Heidi Jensberg. information, please contact authors. information class schema, please check references : Leiulfsrud, H., . code: library(dplyr)  # E.O Wright - Simple translation ess %>%   transmute(     isco88com,     wr_simple = isco88com_to_wright(       isco88com,       is_supervisor,       self_employed,       emplno,       control_work,       control_daily,       type = "simple"     ),     wr_simple_label = isco88com_to_wright(       isco88com,       is_supervisor,       self_employed,       emplno,       control_work,       control_daily,       type = "simple",       label = TRUE     )   ) #> # A tibble: 48,285 √ó 3 #>    isco88com wr_simple wr_simple_label            #>    <chr>     <chr>     <chr>                      #>  1 5169      3         Self empl w/no empoyees    #>  2 1222      7         Skilled manager/superv     #>  3 8120      12        Low skilled workers        #>  4 7141      7         Skilled manager/superv     #>  5 6111      9         Skilled workers            #>  6 6111      7         Skilled manager/superv     #>  7 9313      10        Low skilled manager/superv #>  8 1221      7         Skilled manager/superv     #>  9 1221      2         Self empl w/1-9 employees  #> 10 6111      7         Skilled manager/superv     #> # ‚Ñπ 48,275 more rows  # E.O Wright - Decision-making translation ess %>%   transmute(     isco88com,     wr_decision = isco88com_to_wright(       isco88com,       is_supervisor,       self_employed,       emplno,       control_work,       control_daily,       type = "decision-making"     ),     wr_decision_label = isco88com_to_wright(       isco88com,       is_supervisor,       self_employed,       emplno,       control_work,       control_daily,       type = "decision-making",       label = TRUE     )   ) #> # A tibble: 48,285 √ó 3 #>    isco88com wr_decision wr_decision_label         #>    <chr>     <chr>       <chr>                     #>  1 5169      3           Self empl w/no empoyees   #>  2 1222      9           Skilled workers           #>  3 8120      NA          NA                        #>  4 7141      9           Skilled workers           #>  5 6111      9           Skilled workers           #>  6 6111      8           Skilled supervisors       #>  7 9313      NA          NA                        #>  8 1221      NA          NA                        #>  9 1221      2           Self empl w/1-9 employees #> 10 6111      NA          NA                        #> # ‚Ñπ 48,275 more rows  # E.O Wright - Power-class translation ess %>%   transmute(     isco88com,     wr_power = isco88com_to_wright(       isco88com,       is_supervisor,       self_employed,       emplno,       control_work,       control_daily,       type = "power-class"     ),     wr_power_label = isco88com_to_wright(       isco88com,       is_supervisor,       self_employed,       emplno,       control_work,       control_daily,       type = "power-class",       label = TRUE     )   ) #> # A tibble: 48,285 √ó 3 #>    isco88com wr_power wr_power_label      #>    <chr>     <chr>    <chr>               #>  1 5169      3        Self empl           #>  2 1222      7        Skilled workers     #>  3 8120      NA       NA                  #>  4 7141      7        Skilled workers     #>  5 6111      7        Skilled workers     #>  6 6111      5        Skilled supervisors #>  7 9313      NA       NA                  #>  8 1221      NA       NA                  #>  9 1221      2        Small Employers     #> 10 6111      NA       NA                  #> # ‚Ñπ 48,275 more rows

what: Fill ISCO codes with trailing zeros ‚Äî isco_fill
title: Fill ISCO codes with trailing zeros ‚Äî isco_fill
text: function converts ISCO codes digit level specified target digit format appending trailing zeros. useful preparing codes functions expect specific digit lengths, isco*_to_oep() expects 4-digit input.

title: Fill ISCO codes with trailing zeros ‚Äî isco_fill
code: isco_fill(x, digits = 4, isco_type = NULL)

title: Fill ISCO codes with trailing zeros ‚Äî isco_fill
text: x character numeric vector ISCO codes digits Target number digits (1, 2, 3, 4). Default 4. isco_type Optional. Specify "isco08", "isco88", "isco68" validation

title: Fill ISCO codes with trailing zeros ‚Äî isco_fill
text: character vector ISCO codes specified digit level

title: Fill ISCO codes with trailing zeros ‚Äî isco_fill
text: function automatically detects digit level input codes fills target format appending trailing zeros: 1-digit codes (e.g., "6") become "6000" (digits=4) 2-digit codes (e.g., "61") become "6100" (digits=4) 3-digit codes (e.g., "611") become "6110" (digits=4) Codes already target length remain unchanged follows logic CROSSWALK/ISCOGEN Stata. Note function expands codes (adds zeros) - reduce digit levels, use isco*_swap() instead.

title: Fill ISCO codes with trailing zeros ‚Äî isco_fill
code: # Fill 1-digit codes to 4-digit (default) isco_fill(c("1", "2", "6"))  # Returns: c("1000", "2000", "6000") #> ‚Ñπ Filled 1-digit ISCO codes to 4-digit format #> [1] "1000" "2000" "6000"  # Fill 2-digit codes to 4-digit   isco_fill(c("11", "21", "61"))  # Returns: c("1100", "2100", "6100") #> ‚Ñπ Filled 2-digit ISCO codes to 4-digit format #> [1] "1100" "2100" "6100"  # Fill 1-digit codes to 3-digit isco_fill(c("1", "2", "6"), digits = 3)  # Returns: c("100", "200", "600") #> ‚Ñπ Filled 1-digit ISCO codes to 3-digit format #> [1] "100" "200" "600"  # Fill 2-digit codes to 3-digit isco_fill(c("11", "21", "61"), digits = 3)  # Returns: c("110", "210", "610") #> ‚Ñπ Filled 2-digit ISCO codes to 3-digit format #> [1] "110" "210" "610"  # 4-digit codes unchanged when digits=4 isco_fill(c("1111", "2111", "6111"))  # Returns: unchanged #> [1] "1111" "2111" "6111"  # Typical workflow for OEP calculation if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(dplyr) your_data %>%   mutate(     isco08_4digit = isco_fill(isco08_2digit),  # Fill to 4-digit     oep = isco08_to_oep(isco08_4digit)   ) } # }
